 Abortion is NOT murder.
 
 1. A fetus is either a "person" or not.

 If I am in a situation where I will die if I do not have your lung transplanted into my body, I still cannot REQUIRE that you let me use your lung... even temporarily. Similarily, a fetus (if it "is" a person) cannot REQUIRE that the mother let it use her organs to prolong its life.
 
 There is an inherent maternal responsibility when the risk is taken and often abortion is a means of escaping that responsibility, but it is NOT murder.

We are going in circles here, the issuse where does a individual person start is actually a lot harder to define that people would think. At conception the combination of DNA that will be unique to the person is created, however if the DNA replication process of an egg was stimulated then you would have all the DNA you need for a human and it would be different from its mother. But we can't just use DNA to classify a human otherwise cancer cells become humans (they fit it better than a fetus does even, having all the genetic data required for a complete organism, are different albeit very slightly from the parent, being able to replicate themsleves and surive independantly of another person) and it gets very messy if you start going back in time and get evolution involved. 
 
 The changing back bit was in reference to them being human before they split to become gametes, then they arn't until when they combine with another gamete to become human again. Classifing them as only for reproductive use is a bit of an issuse (although eggs to carry out more functions that just potentially become a zygote, there are hormones released though again they are still reproductive based), as far as the body (or at least the DNA controlling it), reproduction is as important to it as being able to digest protein (more important really).

 I'm not certain what you are suggesting here, as I do not know how to interpret your semantics of certain terms and ideas. However, it appears that your arguments are not biologically sound.
 
 A sperm is an individual physical entity that will die as a sperm unless it fertilizes an ovum. An ovum is an individual physical entity that will die as an ovum unless it is fertilized by a sperm. On their own, they are cells from a parent organism. It is necessary that they join in order to create a new and unique member of the species (defined here simply by a unique entity that has everything that it needs save nourishment, oxygen, and a safe environment to grow into an adult member of the species). Once they join, this new and unique entity is created. Nothing need be added to that entity during it's entire biological life except nourishment and oxygen in order that it may continue to grow and develop.
 
 OR... try this on... (I already posted this elsewhere in these forums, but figured it applied here, too.)
 
 Try a different approach for a moment... And please take this for what it is: a simple example. I do not care to discuss philosophy in this thread, so while you are certainly welcome to go there, I likely will not respond.
 
 The physical 'you' exists today. Your body can be seen, touched (scandalous!), smelled (eewww!), etc. Can you accept that?
 
 If there is a physical mass that is uniquely 'you' today, then either the 'physical' you has always existed, or it had a definite starting point. Unless you get metaphysical, it would be difficult to argue rationally that you always existed. Can you accept that?
 
 If you accept these statements, then the physical 'you' had a definite starting point. (If you see another option, please fill me in.)
 
 When was the starting point of the physical you?
 
 When you first had sex? (Let's get physical!) When you learned to drive? When you recognized your first thought as your own thought? When you were born? No, your physical body existed before all of these things happened. So, when did the physical 'you' begin developing? (Note that I am not discussing 'your personality' or any such thing -- only your physical body.) The answer goes back through your development to the time of conception/fertilization. Prior to conception, the physical 'you' did not exist. Only a sperm and an egg existed that joined to become the physical 'you.' Post-conception, there was not any point at which the developing 'blob of cells' transformed into the physical 'you.' Rather the blob of cells was the physical 'you' in the earliest stages of biological development.

 Perhaps I should rephrase that:
 I believe we are the sole owners of our own body. It is our right to do or not to do to our own bodies as we see fit. 
 
 Someone choosing to not donate a kidney is doing to their body as they wish. No one else has the right to lay claim to their body. 
 
 The person wanting a kidney has the right to do to their body as they wish. 
 
 Both people can have their right existing together. It is not one or the other. If the person needing a kidney forcably takes one from another person then their right is clashing with anothers right. 
 
 Pregnacy is interwined so that a decision affects two different peoples choices. The life does not exist untill conception. The mother has the right to get or not get pregnant. Once pregnant the life exists and so also has a right to do to its body as it wishes (As it is not then self aware that is the wrong language to use, but I think it is fair to say that the lifes purpose is to grow and live).  To summarise 
 the right of one forcably contradicts anothers.
 Neither is guilty, the women did not choose to get pregnant, the child did not exist till conception.
 Therefore we must choose whose right is the more valid. The life of the child or the forced sharing of the mothers body for 9 months.
